book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: respectful affection of their offspring on such terms.  They demand

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: blind obedience, because they do not merit a reasonable service:

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: and to render these demands of weakness and ignorance more binding,

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: a mysterious sanctity is spread round the most arbitrary principle;

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: for what other name can be given to the blind duty of obeying

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: vicious or weak beings, merely because they obeyed a powerful

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: instinct? The simple definition of the reciprocal duty, which

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: naturally subsists between parent and child, may be given in a few

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: words:  The parent who pays proper attention to helpless infancy

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: has a right to require the same attention when the feebleness of

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: age comes upon him.  But to subjugate a rational being to the mere

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: will of another, after he is of age to answer to society for his

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: own conduct, is a most cruel and undue stretch of power; and

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: perhaps as injurious to morality, as those religious systems which

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: do not allow right and wrong to have any existence, but in the

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: Divine will.

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: I never knew a parent who had paid more than common attention to

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: his children, disregarded (Dr. Johnson makes the same

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: observation.); on the contrary, the early habit of relying almost

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: implicitly on the opinion of a respected parent is not easily

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: shaken, even when matured reason convinces the child that his

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: father is not the wisest man in the world.  This weakness, for a

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: weakness it is, though the epithet AMIABLE may be tacked to it, a

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: reasonable man must steel himself against; for the absurd duty, too

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: often inculcated, of obeying a parent only on account of his being

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: a parent, shackles the mind, and prepares it for a slavish

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: submission to any power but reason.

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: I distinguish between the natural and accidental duty due to

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: parents.

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: The parent who sedulously endeavours to form the heart and enlarge

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: the understanding of his child, has given that dignity to the

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: discharge of a duty, common to the whole animal world, that only

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: reason can give.  This is the parental affection of humanity, and

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: leaves instinctive natural affection far behind.  Such a parent

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: acquires all the rights of the most sacred friendship, and his

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: advice, even when his child is advanced in life, demands serious

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: consideration.

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: With respect to marriage, though after one and twenty a parent

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: seems to have no right to withhold his consent on any account; yet

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: twenty years of solicitude call for a return, and the son ought, at

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: least, to promise not to marry for two or three years, should the

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: object of his choice not entirely meet with the approbation of his

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: first friend.

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: But, respect for parents is, generally speaking, a much more

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: debasing principle; it is only a selfish respect for property.  The

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: father who is blindly obeyed, is obeyed from sheer weakness, or

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: from motives that degrade the human character.

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: A great proportion of the misery that wanders, in hideous forms

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: around the world, is allowed to rise from the negligence of

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: parents; and still these are the people who are most tenacious of

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: what they term a natural right, though it be subversive of the

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: birth right of man, the right of acting according to the direction

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: of his own reason.

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: I have already very frequently had occasion to observe, that

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: vicious or indolent people are always eager to profit by enforcing

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: arbitrary privileges; and generally in the same proportion as they

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: neglect the discharge of the duties which alone render the

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: privileges reasonable.  This is at the bottom, a dictate of common

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: sense, or the instinct of self-defence, peculiar to ignorant

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: weakness; resembling that instinct, which makes a fish muddy the

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: water it swims in to elude its enemy, instead of boldly facing it

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: in the clear stream.

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: >From the clear stream of argument, indeed, the supporters of

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: prescription, of every denomination, fly:  and taking refuge in the

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: darkness, which, in the language of sublime poetry, has been

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: supposed to surround the throne of Omnipotence, they dare to demand

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: that implicit respect which is only due to His unsearchable ways.

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: But, let me not be thought presumptuous, the darkness which hides

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: our God from us, only respects speculative truths-- it never

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: obscures moral ones, they shine clearly, for God is light, and

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: never, by the constitution of our nature, requires the discharge of

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: a duty, the reasonableness of which does not beam on us when we

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: open our eyes.

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: The indolent parent of high rank may, it is true, extort a show of

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: respect from his child, and females on the continent are

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: particularly subject to the views of their families, who never

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: think of consulting their inclination, or providing for the comfort

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: of the poor victims of their pride.  The consequence is notorious;

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: these dutiful daughters become adulteresses, and neglect the

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: education of their children, from whom they, in their turn, exact

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: the same kind of obedience.

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: Females, it is true, in all countries, are too much under the

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: dominion of their parents; and few parents think of addressing

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: their children in the following manner, though it is in this

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: reasonable way that Heaven seems to command the whole human race.

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: It is your interest to obey me till you can judge for yourself; and

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: the Almighty Father of all has implanted an affection in me to

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: serve as a guard to you whilst your reason is unfolding; but when

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: your mind arrives at maturity, you must only obey me, or rather

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: respect my opinions, so far as they coincide with the light that is

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: breaking in on your own mind.

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: A slavish bondage to parents cramps every faculty of the mind; and

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: Mr. Locke very judiciously observes, that "if the mind be curbed

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: and humbled too much in children; if their spirits be abased and

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: broken much by too strict an hand over them; they lose all their

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: vigour and industry."  This strict hand may, in some degree,

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: account for the weakness of women; for girls, from various causes,

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: are more kept down by their parents, in every sense of the word,

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: than boys.  The duty expected from them is, like all the duties

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: arbitrarily imposed on women, more from a sense of propriety, more

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: out of respect for decorum, than reason; and thus taught slavishly

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: to submit to their parents, they are prepared for the slavery of

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: marriage.  I may be told that a number of women are not slaves in

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: the marriage state.  True, but they then become tyrants; for it is

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: not rational freedom, but a lawless kind of power, resembling the

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: authority exercised by the favourites of absolute monarchs, which

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: they obtain by debasing means.  I do not, likewise, dream of

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: insinuating that either boys or girls are always slaves, I only

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: insist, that when they are obliged to submit to authority blindly,

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: their faculties are weakened, and their tempers rendered imperious

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: or abject.  I also lament, that parents, indolently availing

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: themselves of a supposed privilege, damp the first faint glimmering

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: of reason rendering at the same time the duty, which they are so

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: anxious to enforce, an empty name; because they will not let it

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: rest on the only basis on which a duty can rest securely:  for,

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: unless it be founded on knowledge, it cannot gain sufficient

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: strength to resist the squalls of passion, or the silent sapping of

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: self-love.  But it is not the parents who have given the surest

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: proof of their affection for their children, (or, to speak more

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: properly, who by fulfilling their duty, have allowed a natural

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: parental affection to take root in their hearts, the child of

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: exercised sympathy and reason, and not the over-weening offspring

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: of selfish pride,) who most vehemently insist on their children

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: submitting to their will, merely because it is their will.  On the

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: contrary, the parent who sets a good example, patiently lets that

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: example work; and it seldom fails to produce its natural

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: effect--filial respect.

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: Children cannot be taught too early to submit to reason, the true

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: definition of that necessity, which Rousseau insisted on, without

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: defining it; for to submit to reason, is to submit to the nature of

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: things, and to that God who formed them so, to promote our real

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: interest.

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: Why should the minds of children be warped as they just begin to

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: expand, only to favour the indolence of parents, who insist on a

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: privilege without being willing to pay the price fixed by nature?

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: I have before had occasion to observe, that a right always includes

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: a duty, and I think it may, likewise fairly be inferred, that they

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: forfeit the right, who do not fulfil the duty.

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: It is easier, I grant, to command than reason; but it does not

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: follow from hence, that children cannot comprehend the reason why

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: they are made to do certain things habitually; for, from a steady

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: adherence to a few simple principles of conduct flows that salutary

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: power, which a judicious parent gradually gains over a child's

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: mind.  And this power becomes strong indeed, if tempered by an even

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: display of affection brought home to the child's heart.  For, I

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: believe, as a general rule, it must be allowed, that the affection

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: which we inspire always resembles that we cultivate; so that

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: natural affections, which have been supposed almost distinct from

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: reason, may be found more nearly connected with judgment than is

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: commonly allowed.  Nay, as another proof of the necessity of

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: cultivating the female understanding, it is but just to observe,

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: that the affections seem to have a kind of animal capriciousness

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: when they merely reside in the heart.

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: It is the irregular exercise of parental authority that first

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: injures the mind, and to these irregularities girls are more

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: subject than boys.  The will of those who never allow their will to

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: be disputed, unless they happen to be in a good humour, when they

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: relax proportionally, is almost always unreasonable.  To elude this

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: arbitrary authority, girls very early learn the lessons which they

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: afterwards practise on their husbands; for I have frequently seen a

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: little sharp-faced miss rule a whole family, excepting that now and

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: then mamma's anger will burst out of some accidental cloud-- either

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: her hair was ill-dressed,* or she had lost more money at cards, the

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: night before, than she was willing to own to her husband; or some

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: such moral cause of anger.

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: (*Footnote.  I myself heard a little girl once say to a servant,

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: "My mamma has been scolding me finely this morning, because her

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: hair was not dressed to please her."  Though this remark was pert,

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: it was just.  And what respect could a girl acquire for such a

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: parent, without doing violence to reason?)

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: After observing sallies of this kind, I have been led into a

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: melancholy train of reflection respecting females, concluding that

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: when their first affection must lead them astray, or make their

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: duties clash till they rest on mere whims and customs, little can

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: be expected from them as they advance in life.  How, indeed, can an

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: instructor remedy this evil? for to teach them virtue on any solid

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: principle is to teach them to despise their parents.  Children

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: cannot, ought not to be taught to make allowance for the faults of

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: their parents, because every such allowance weakens the force of

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: reason in their minds, and makes them still more indulgent to their

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: own.  It is one of the most sublime virtues of maturity that leads

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: us to be severe with respect to ourselves, and forbearing to

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: others; but children should only be taught the simple virtues, for

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: if they begin too early to make allowance for human passions and

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: manners, they wear off the fine edge of the criterion by which they

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: should regulate their own, and become unjust in the same proportion

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: as they grow indulgent.

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: The affections of children, and weak people, are always selfish;

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: they love others, because others love them, and not on account of

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: their virtues.  Yet, till esteem and love are blended together in

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: the first affection, and reason made the foundation of the first

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: duty, morality will stumble at the threshold.  But, till society is

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: very differently constituted, parents, I fear, will still insist on

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: being obeyed, because they will be obeyed, and constantly endeavour

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: to settle that power on a Divine right, which will not bear the

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: investigation of reason.

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: CHAPTER 12.

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: ON NATIONAL EDUCATION.

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: The good effects resulting from attention to private education will

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: ever be very confined, and the parent who really puts his own hand

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: to the plow, will always, in some degree be disappointed, till

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: education becomes a grand national concern.  A man cannot retire

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: into a desert with his child, and if he did, he could not bring

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: himself back to childhood, and become the proper friend and

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: play-fellow of an infant or youth.  And when children are confined

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: to the society of men and women, they very soon acquire that kind

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: of premature manhood which stops the growth of every vigorous power

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: of mind or body.  In order to open their faculties they should be

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
book: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman
text: excited to think for themselves; and this can only be done by

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
